      58                 :            : /* generate GF(2^mm) from the irreducible polynomial p(X) in pp[0]..pp[mm]
      59                 :            :    lookup tables:  index->polynomial form   alpha_to[] contains j=alpha**i;
      60                 :            :                    polynomial form -> index form  index_of[j=alpha**i] = i
      61                 :            :    alpha=2 is the primitive element of GF(2^mm)
      62                 :            : */
      63                 :          0 : void RScodec::RSgenerate_gf( unsigned int pp )
      64                 :            : {
      65                 :          0 :   int i, mask ;
      66                 :            :   int pb;
      67                 :            : 
      68                 :          0 :   mask = 1 ;
      69                 :          0 :   alpha_to[mm] = 0 ;
      70                 :          0 :   for ( i = 0; i < mm; i++ )
      71                 :            :   {
      72                 :          0 :     alpha_to[i] = mask ;
      73                 :          0 :     index_of[alpha_to[i]] = i ;
      74                 :          0 :     pb = ( pp >> ( mm - 1 - i ) ) & 1;
      75                 :          0 :     if ( pb != 0 )
      76                 :            :     {
      77                 :          0 :       alpha_to[mm] ^= mask;
      78                 :          0 :     }
      79                 :          0 :     mask <<= 1 ;
      80                 :          0 :   }
      81                 :          0 :   index_of[alpha_to[mm]] = mm ;
      82                 :          0 :   mask >>= 1 ;
      83                 :          0 :   for ( i = mm + 1; i < nn; i++ )
      84                 :            :   {
      85                 :          0 :     if ( alpha_to[i - 1] >= mask )
      86                 :            :     {
      87                 :          0 :       alpha_to[i] = alpha_to[mm] ^ ( ( alpha_to[i - 1] ^ mask ) << 1 ) ;
      88                 :          0 :     }
      89                 :          0 :     else alpha_to[i] = alpha_to[i - 1] << 1 ;
      90                 :          0 :     index_of[alpha_to[i]] = i ;
      91                 :          0 :   }
      92                 :          0 :   index_of[0] = UINT_MAX;
      93                 :          0 : }

      96                 :            : /* Obtain the generator polynomial of the tt-error correcting, length
      97                 :            :   nn=(2^mm -1) Reed Solomon code  from the product of (X+alpha**i), i=1..2*tt

     114                 :          0 :         tmp = ( index_of[gg[j]] + i ) % nn;

     164                 :            :   /* errors are present, try and correct */
     165                 :            :   /* compute the error location polynomial via the Berlekamp iterative algorithm,
     166                 :            :   following the terminology of Lin and Costello :   d[u] is the 'mu'th
     167                 :            :   discrepancy, where u='mu'+1 and 'mu' (the Greek letter!) is the step number
     168                 :            :   ranging from -1 to 2*tt (see L&C),  l[u] is the
     169                 :            :   degree of the elp at that step, and u_l[u] is the difference between the
     170                 :            :   step number and the degree of the elp.
     171                 :            :   */
     172                 :            :   /* initialize table entries */
     173                 :          0 :   d[0] = 0;           /* index form */
     174                 :          0 :   d[1] = s[1];        /* index form */
     175                 :          0 :   elp[0][0] = 0;      /* index form */

     316                 :          0 :     }
     317                 :          0 :     else if ( ( s[i] != -1 ) && ( elp[u][i] == -1 ) )

     320                 :          0 :     }

     363                 :          0 :       err[loc[i]] = alpha_to[( err[loc[i]] - q + nn ) % nn];

     365                 :          0 :     }
     366                 :          0 :   }

     368                 :          0 : }
     369                 :            : 
     370                 :            : /** Take the string of symbols in data[i], i=0..(k-1) and encode systematically
     371                 :            :    to produce 2*tt parity symbols in bd[0]..bd[2*tt-1]
     372                 :            :    data[] is input and bd[] is output in polynomial form.
     373                 :            :    Encoding is done by using a feedback shift register with appropriate
     374                 :            :    connections specified by the elements of gg[], which was generated above.
     375                 :            :    Codeword is   c(X) = data(X)*X**(nn-kk)+ b(X)         */
     376                 :          0 : bool RScodec::encode( unsigned char *data, unsigned char *parity )
     377                 :            : {
     378                 :          0 :   if ( !isOk ) return false;
     379                 :            :   int i, j ;
     380                 :            :   int feedback ;
     381                 :          0 :   unsigned char *idata = data;
     382                 :          0 :   unsigned char *bd = parity;
     383                 :          0 :   int bb = nn - kk;; //nn-kk length of parity data
     384                 :            : 
     385                 :          0 :   for ( i = 0; i < bb; i++ )   bd[i] = 0 ;
     386                 :          0 :   for ( i = kk - 1; i >= 0; i-- )
     387                 :            :   {
     388                 :          0 :     feedback = index_of[idata[i] ^ bd[bb - 1]] ;
     389                 :          0 :     if ( feedback != -1 )
     390                 :            :     {
     391                 :          0 :       for ( j = bb - 1; j > 0; j-- )
     392                 :          0 :         if ( gg[j] != -1 )
     393                 :          0 :           bd[j] = bd[j - 1] ^ alpha_to[( gg[j] + feedback ) % nn] ;
     394                 :            :         else
     395                 :          0 :           bd[j] = bd[j - 1] ;
     396                 :          0 :       bd[0] = alpha_to[( gg[0] + feedback ) % nn] ;
     397                 :          0 :     }
     398                 :            :     else
     399                 :            :     {
     400                 :          0 :       for ( j = bb - 1; j > 0; j-- )
     401                 :          0 :         bd[j] = bd[j - 1] ;
     402                 :          0 :       bd[0] = 0 ;
     403                 :            :     }
     404                 :          0 :   }
     405                 :          0 :   return true;
     406                 :          0 : }
     407                 :            : 
     408                 :            : 
     409                 :            : /* assume we have received bits grouped into mm-bit symbols in recd[i],
     410                 :            :    i=0..(nn-1),  and recd[i] is index form (ie as powers of alpha).
     411                 :            :    We first compute the 2*tt syndromes by substituting alpha**i into rec(X) and
     412                 :            :    evaluating, storing the syndromes in s[i], i=1..2tt (leave s[0] zero) .
     413                 :            :    Then we use the Berlekamp iteration to find the error location polynomial
     414                 :            :    elp[i].   If the degree of the elp is >tt, we cannot correct all the errors
     415                 :            :    and hence just put out the information symbols unmodified. If the degree of
     416                 :            :    elp is <=tt, we substitute alpha**i , i=1..n into the elp to get the roots,
     417                 :            :    hence the inverse roots, the error location numbers. If the number of errors
     418                 :            :    located does not equal the degree of the elp, we have more than tt errors
     419                 :            :    and cannot correct them.  Otherwise, we then solve for the error value at
     420                 :            :    the error location and correct the error.  The procedure is that found in
     421                 :            :    Lin and Costello. For the cases where the number of errors is known to be too
     422                 :            :    large to correct, the information symbols as received are output (the
     423                 :            :    advantage of systematic encoding is that hopefully some of the information
     424                 :            :    symbols will be okay and that if we are in luck, the errors are in the
     425                 :            :    parity part of the transmitted codeword).  Of course, these insoluble cases
     426                 :            :    can be returned as error flags to the calling routine if desired.   */
     427                 :            : //! Return value: number of corrected errors or -1 if can't correct it
